Sunny Berkeley: where have all the riots gone?
By ERIC GARLAND
Berkeley is a nice place to
be this time of year. The
temperature hovers around
sixty degrees, and there's not
much rain. You can sun
yourself in one of the grassy
areas that are spread all
around the campus, reading in
a calm, quiet atmosphere. . .
Wait! Isn't this Berkeley,
the famous University of
golden California, Mecca to
all would-be shouters and
snorters? We.., yes, but it's
not the same—like who's
going to listen to Mickiagger
when he's 40? The Free
Speech movement has passed
its twelfth anniversary, has
become history; some
professor has "conceptualized" it into a chapter in his
textbook and is probably
even teaching freshmen about
those wild and wondrous
times of the sixties. (Final
Exam—Part II: Identify and
discuss the significance of the
following: Mario Savio,
People's Park, etc.)
Don't think, however, that
the place has turned into
Ronald Reagan's idea of a
University; there's more going
on at Berkeley during a single
day than happens at Hopkins

•
over a two-month period. It's
just a different tone You can
walk up and down Telegraph
Avenue today and not once
(not even at night!) be
offered various kinds of drugs
and stimulants. People are
still handing out leaflets or
holding coin boxes on most
corners, but they're for new
restaurants, Iranian prisoners,
mystic churches—no
"at-home" causes or rallies.
The most inflammatory
subject in Berkeley is the
closing off of residential
streets to thru traffic. There's
been crashing, of street
barricades, but what kind of
protest is violence against
traffic regulations? And the
biggest excitement during the
fall was caused by the
football team - that's what
they go crazy about in
Oklahoma!
Still, as I sit here smashing
cockroaches on the wall with
a Pittsburgh Penguin cast-iron
paperweight, and begin to
think about Greenmount
Avenue, then about Telegraph
. . . no contest. Four record
stores, half a dozen
bookstores, all sorts of shops
and restaurants, without
obnoxious employees;

although no one is making
speeches at Sather Gate,
there's always some form of
entertainment or show going
on. And as for the Bay Area
as opposed to Baltimore, well,
where else can you see Steve
McQueen and Ali McGraw, as
real people, in the same
clothes store that you're in?
True excitement! Seriously,
though, there are good places.
. . like Golden Gate Park
(with San Francisco visible on
one side, the Pacific on the

Berkeley
other) where you can have
lunch in an abandoned
30-year old pillbox, waiting
and watching for the Japanese
to come across the ocean. The
water is contaminated,
though, probably by the
Army, which still owns most
of the land in and around the
park.
What I said earlier about no
political activity isn't entirely
true. Every other week some
Bank of America branch is
either threatened or actually

bombed, and city officials
receive suspicious packages
routinely. There's vicarious
interest in Patty Hearst
(mostly due to Citizen
Randolph's front-page
treatment of her case), and
Lynette Fromme and Charles
Manson get a lot of graffiti
support. On the campus itself,
however, quite a few students
seem to be most concerned
with issues such as, uh, med
school. It's 1976, not 1966.
Happy Bicentennial.

Between the mob and the men in blue: Crazy Joey
By RUSS SMITH
"Born in Red Hook,
Brooklyn in the year of who
knows when
Opened up his eyes, to the
tune of the accordion
Always on the outside, of
whatever side there was
When they asked him why
it had to be that way
Well, the answer was just
because
Larry was the oldest, Joey
Was next to last
They called Joe craxy, the
baby they called Kid Blast
Some said they lived off
gambling, and running
numbers too
Always seemed they caught
between, the mob and the
men in blue
Joey. Joey
King of the streets, child of
pain
Joey, Joey
What made them want to
come and blow you away."
—"Joey," Bob Dylan
Joey Gallo never had it so
good.
Almost four years ago,
Gallo was gunned down in
Umberto's Clam House, a
small restaurant in New
York's Little Italy. Ile was
the victim of a classic
gangland execution, one that
was suspiciously similar to a
scene in the most famous film
of the day, "The Godfather."
Gallo's obituaries depicted
him as a mean and hard-nosed
killer, a "maverick mafioso"
who boasted of being picked
up by the cops 150 times.
The newsweeklies told tales
of Gallo "puncturing his
enemies with iee picks just for
the hell of it" and "gaining
status by serving as a member
f a five man execution squad

dirtected by mafia boss Joe
Profaci in the late fifties.
Gallo's was the most difficult
kind of death for the public
to react to; no one likes to
hear of death, particularly
cold-blooded murder, but in
Gallo's case only an insider
could share in his family's
grief. In short, public school
in New York was not closed
in mourning for Joey Gallo.
Not even in Little Italy.
Therefore, it is not
surprising that a number of
people, especially New
Yorkers, are perplexed by
Bob Dylan's glorification of
Joey Gallo's crime and
bullet-ridden life on his latest
album,Desire.
Dylan takes a professed
"hard-as-nails" gangster and
portrays him as a family man
who, as a pawn of chance,
was led astray. According to
Dylan, Gallo never carried a
gun because "I'm around too
many children, they should
neven know of one." He sings
of Gallo's release from Attica
prison; "they let him out in
'71, he lost a little weight, but
he dressed like Jimmy
Cagney, and I swear he did
look great." To one who is
not familiar with Gallo the
romanticism is just another
element of the song, meshed
well with Dylan's finest vocal
and phrasing on the album.
However, for those who grew
up reading page three stories
and photo spreads about
Gallo's killings and mob
dealings in newspapers like
the New York Daily News
and National Enquirer, the
song is unsettling at best.
Dylan's intentions remain a
puzzle. Was he consciously
attempting to rescue Gallo

from the ranks of Mafia
infamy or was he taken in by
the folksy aura that "led
some of his superficial
acquantances to consider him
a sort of folk hero"? It's hard
to believe that Dylan, a
resident of New York
throughout the sixties, would
write such a naive ballad
about a mobster who
delighted in breaking arms
and spitting at subordinates.
They didn't call Joey Gallo
crazy for nothing.
It seems more probable
that Gallo's new status as a
martyr and folk hero was
calculated very carefully by
Dylan. By decriminalizing
Gallo, Dylan has placed Gallo

on the pedestal shared by the
likes of Jesse James and Billy
the Kid, two of the
songwriter's favorite models
in previous work. James and
Billy the Kid have been
cloaked in mystique since
their death and as the years
pass their image grows while
their villainous lives are
forgotten. Of course, it takes
more than one song for a
legend of this type to catch
on, but it is songs like "Joey"
that add to a myth and spread
it.
Thirty years from now,
after Gallo's crimes have been
forgotten, the gangster will
have been transformed into
"Joey, king of the streets,

child of clay." All that will
survive will be the legend of
Joey Gallo and Dylan will be
lost in the years, for a legend
is bigger than any man.
That Dylan uses a
contemporary gangster as his
latest folk model is an
example of his desperate need
for changing his music and
writing. The main differences '
in Dylan's writing about Gallo

A New Hampshire experience
By JAN HAMMERMAN
Nashua New Hampshire is
like a woman. She will be
tantalizingly warm with a
balmy 30o in the daytime...
and then whip up twenty mile
per hour winds as the
temperature drops to 10o
below zero at night. There
were times when I wondered
whether this phenomenon
was natural or a ploy by some
higher authority to discourage
the assorted ne'er — do —
wells who trek on the icy
New England roads every four
years, plugging away for some
candidate who in six months
will be selling old campaign
buttons to a scrap metal
dealer.
With apologies to Dr. Burns
(see article 1/23/76) the New
Hampshire campaign is not
quite as amusing as starring in
a porno film. Rather, it is a
grueling lesson on how to
coax out the most votes for
your candidate, avoiding a
bad back while sleeping on
two sleeping bags, vnd
praying for a miracle in
modern preventive medicine
as you co-habit an area with a
half wolf—half dog who has
yet to be dewormed. A
primary campaign is not for
those with picky appetites
either; unless one considers
peanut butter on anything
with a glass of milk to be the
pinnacle of haute cuisine.
Still, involving myself in
the Udall effort gave me both
a renewed interest in a
campaign which has been
highlighted by Ronald Reagan
chipping a capped tooth as he
put his foot into mouth.
Moreover, I caught a glimpse
of how pleasant life can be in
a city with little to fear but
the "foreign hordes" which

only pop up every four years;
it seems the major crime wave
in Nashua was a rash of
Christmas shoplifting.
The key words to
remember when knocking
doors in Nashua is to be as
soft spoken and innocuous as
possible. New Englanders are
not as cold as their weather,
just reserved. Suffice to say
that Long Islanders would not
be the greatest campaign
workers in this region.
According to Udall's director
of canvassing, Mark
Youngholm, the most
important impression a
campaigner can make on a
voter's memory will be that
of a student braving the cold
and snow simply to work for
Mo Udall.
Vagueness
Sometimes this approach
succeeds, no matter how
masochistic it sounds. At
times, though, the only thing
a potential Udall voter will
say is "Damn, you must be a
moron for being out there."
The New Hampshire
primary is not crucial in the
sense that the winner gets a
large delegation at the
national convention, for New
Hampshire only has seventeen
votes. What makes the state
grow out of proportion in
relation to political strength,
is that the winner of the
contest receives tremendous
immediate coverage from the
national press with all the
benefits that exposure brings
with it (cash, volunteers,
endorsements). Additionally,
it helps make also-rans out of
some aspirants for the Oval
office, and thus cuts the
Democratic field from one
resembling the race up San
Juan Hill to one bearing a

similarity to the fifth at
Aqueduct. What is equally
remarkable about this
election is that it can make
winners of the final tally into
losers: few people will
remember that LBJ beat
Eugene McCarthy there in
1968, or that a 'tearful'
Edmund Muskie defeated
George McGovern, putting
the Democratic Party in a
state of chaos. From the
number of Demociatic voters
met, who are supporting
Ronald Reagan, it appears
that President Ford may yet
be another name placed on
that list of vanquished victors.
Presently, chances are that
the democratic winner will
probably be either Jimmy
Carter or Udall. Both men
seem to have the best
campaign organizations.
efficient campaign techniques
and most critically, the
greatest number of volunteers
to canvass the state with. If
Udall does win, he will get a
needed boost after the
disastrous Iowa caucus and
perhaps gain enough
momentum to place in the
top three in the Massachusetts
primary. Carter, on the other
hand, should be well satisfied
with a second place finish in a
Yankee state, especially after
his Iowa victory and an
expected moral triumph over
George Wallace at the
Mississippi caucus. Should the
former Georgian governor
lead the pack in New
Hampshire, though, and
subsequently make strong .
showings in North Carolina,
Florida, and Illinois, Carter
may well be the de facto
Democratic nominee for
president come July.

To the Editor:
1 take my teaching
seriously. I take student
responses to my teaching
seriously. For that reason I
wish to take the unusual step
of responding to several
related points in the Fall
1975 Course Evaluation of
my "Changing China" course.
The course guide, based I
believe in part on an
inaccurate assessment of
certain facts and in part on an
all -too -reasonable
misunderstanding of other
facts, states: "Grading is
rather strict and even a bit
prejudicial—i.e., essay exam
questions are vague and must
be answered just right and
favorably to China. Dr.
Pfeffer considers a 'C' a good
grade and the majority of
grades given out were 'good
grades'."
In response, I do not and
never have considered a "C" a
good grade. Personally, I
consider it less than
satisfactory work, and I tell
my students that. Moreover,
the last time the course was
offered, under the title

"China Today," the majority
of grades were not "C's," as
the report seems to imply. To
be precise, of the 16 grades
given, 3 Were "A's," 7 were
"B's" and only 3 were "C's:"
one was a pass and two were
incompletes. The only
substance to the charge that
"grading is rather strict" is
that I have resisted the total
surrender to grade inflation
reflected at Hopkins today.
More importantly, the
report charges that my
grading is "even a bit
prejudicial"—equivalent to
the kiss of death in a
"value -free," liberal
university. And further that
essay exam questions are
"vague" and "must be
answered just right and
favorably to China." This is a
more complex and difficult
charge to rebut, involving as it
does different ideologies. Let
me try to respond.
First, I do not think that
my grading is any more
"prejudicial" than any other
professor's in the social
sciences or humanities. My
prejudices simply are not

those widely shared by
faculty members and
students, so they are more
obvious. I do not try to
disguise my values.
Nevertheless, I believe I
recognize quality work when
I see it, and I have given
"A's" to well conceived and
executed papers that argued
Mao is a fascist, and
conversely, I have given "C's"
to poorly written,
unthoughtful essays that
simply parrot "the line." In
the final analysis, however, I
recognize that one's ideology
cannot help but influence
how one conceives relevance
and significance. On that
count, I would, with the rest
of humanity, plead guilty.
Second, it is true that my
essay questions are "vague."
They are intended to be, so as
to allow students within a
wide range to answer them as
they think most useful, to
make the questions their own.
That they must be answered
"just right," I think is wrong,
unless by "right" is meant
that the answer must be
logical, well-written,

argumentative, and with some
reasonable connection to
historical fact and a
reasonable use of evidence to
support the arguments. One
rather frequent, half-pained
comment I have had to these
essay questions is that they
"forced" students to think.
Another is that they "forced"
students to try to learn how
to discipline their writing. I
like to believe that is what I
am doing.
That essays must be
favorable to China to be
considered good is, as
indicated above, clearly
wiong as a flat statement. But
the matter is more complex
than .that. My main
substantive goal in the course
is to try to enable students to
understand the Chinese
Revolution in its own terms,
as the Chinese saw it. We
cannot understand why and
how that revolution has
developed if we pose liberal
questions to twentieth
century China, or if we judge
China's Revolution by liberal
standards. China has never
been, is not no'w, art does

not wish to become a liberal
society
I demand is not that
students react "favorably" to
the Chinese Revolution but
that they reach an
understanding of the
revolution in its own terms as
a basis for whatever ultimate
evaluation they may wish to
make. To do otherwise, it
seems to me, entails simply
abdicating on the crucial
matter of understanding a
society so different from and
so alien to our society, and
results in self-satisfying
condemnations of China as
illiberal.
These are difficult matters
to cope with. The line
between understanding and
sympathy, on one hand, and
apology, on the other, can be
very fine. I have tried not to
cross it, though, doubtless, I
have made mistakes. On the
whole, however, I am willing
to stand on what I have done
and on how students have
responded.
Thank you.
Richard M. Pfeffer
Associate Professor

Swordsmen after another winning year
Question: Which one of
Home wood's intercollegiate
athletic teams has been most
successful in terms of national
rankings?
The answer to that is
obvious, the lacrosse team.
But what about the second
most successful team on
campus? The answer to that
question could be one of the
best kept secrets at Hopkins,
even topping some of the
ones down at APL.
If you replied the fencing
team then consider yourself
one of the informed few.
Coach Dick Oles' swordsmen
finished 15th last year in the
University division NCAA
rankings, as well as winning
but h the MAC. and NAC
titles.
The prognosis for this
season was not as good in that
the Blue Jays lost six of their
top fencers to graduation.
Their prospects grew even

dimmer when two other top
team members succumbed to
academic pressures just as the
season started.
Undaunted, Coach Oles
and his resilient charges put
their "swords" to the
grindstone and have built up a
highly respectable (to say the
least) 9-1 record.
Reconstruction
"I was a little bit worried
at the beginning of the season
and then after losing two
additional fencers I was
scared stiff!", noted Oles.
"But with what we have now
we could probably win all but
3 of our remaining meets and
finish 16-4 despite a
rebuilding team."
On epee, Rodgers and Slota
return and according to Oles,
are fencing as well as last year
and that was good enough to
capture titles in both the
MAC and the NAC' No. 3
epee man Frank Murabito

defeated Montclair State's
No. 1 man who, ironically,
defeated both Rodgers and
Slota. Overall, Oles termed
this team as good as last
year's.
"Our foil team is not right
now as good as last year's.
But by the end of the season I
think they will be better than
last year's because there
won't be one flash and three
mediocre fencers. Now we
have better balance,"
according to Oles.
Dave Bell, Dave Graberek
and Eric Newman compose
that trio.
Sabre
"Right now of course,
sabre is our weak link because
we've lost essentially our Nos.
1,2,3 and 4 men from last
season's sabre unit. Our No. 1
man is Ron Kramer who is
our only undefeated fencer
(18-0). He is vastly improved
over last year and could win

the MAC title. No. 2
Streamson Chua and No. 3
Mark Harrison are also
becoming competent
fencers."
The Homewood mentor
concluded,"If everybody
fences as well as they can
then we can win the MAC and
have a longshot at the NAC,
depending on how Chua
comes along because we'll
only need our top two fencers
in each weapon."'
Co-captains Tim Rodgers
and Ron Kramer echoed their
coach's optimistic sentiments.
In looking toward
Saturday's match with
Lafayette, Kramer noted,"We
should repeat as MAC champs
this year and this will be a
good test to see how we stand
vs. up-and-coming MAC
competition." The match will
begin at 2:00 p.m. in the
Hopkins fencing room of the
Athletic Center.

Future lies before inexperienced wrestlers
By DAVID KRAUS
The accent is on the future
as the Johns Hopkins
wrestling team moves into the
second half of its 1975-76
schedule.
First-year coach John
Glascock began the season
with no returning starters
from last year's 8-5 squad and
has turned to a spirited group
of underclassmen to carry the
team.
Sporting a starting line-up
dominated by freshmen and
sophmores, the Blue Jays had
their opening matches in early
December. However, the lack
of team experience proved
costly as they dropped
decisions to UMBC (44-10)
and to Washington College
(27-21).
The new year saw the
losing streak continue as
Susquehanna downed the
men from Homewood.by the
count of 33-12. However, the
Jays broke into the win
column with their next bout.
Led by freshman Muraji
Nakazawa and sophomore
captain McLin Hawkins (a
transfer student from West
Point), Hopkinds thumped
Charles Street rival Loyola,
33-15. Loyola took an early
lead, but several consecutive
victories in the late bouts
assured the Homewood
victory.

This past Saturday, the
Blue Jays travelled to
Lebanon Valley where they
participated in a quadrangular
meet against three different
colleges, including the host
school. Hopkins came away
with a record of 1-2 for the
afternoon, having beaten
Albright, 28-24, while losing
to Scranton, 30-9, and to
Lebanon Valley, 39-11.
Coach Glascock seemed
satisfied with his team's
effort.
"It's tough in the
quadrangular meets," he
explained. "That's a lot of
wrestling in one afternoon.
"I knew Lebanon Valley
would be tough-- they're an
excellent team. Scranton
surprised us— I didn't think
that they'd be as tough as
they were.
"Albright was a hard
match, too. All the guys put
out and it came down to the
last match— which we won."
The team's most recent
bout was Wednesday evening
when Western Maryland
invaded Homewood. The
Green Terrors have a very
powerful squad this year and
had little trouble in
vanquishing the Blue Jays,
46-6.
The only bright spots for
Hopkins were Nakazawa and
Hawkins. Each decisioned

their respective opponent to
keep their personal
undefeated records intact.
Muraji is now 8-0, while
McLin (who missed the first
two matches of the year) is
6-0.
Glscock attributes the
slow start of his team (now
2-6 on the year) to several
factors.

"The team coalesced very
slowly," he noted."We didn't
know who would be returning
from last year's squad and I
was developing a feel for
coaching. In addition, we had
a very large influx of
freshmen.
"However, I would have
thought that our record
would be stronger

during the past two seasons.
The visiting Hounds' 59-56
come from behind win
marked the fifth time in two
years and the second time this
season (79-64 Dec. ( in the,
Metro Tourney) that second
year coach Toni O'Connor
and his charges have
triumphed over the Jays.
A tenacious 2-1-2 zone
defense complemented the
Blue Jays' normal
man-to-man and the two •
combined to force Loyola out
of its normal offense and
caused a number of
Greyhound turnovers.
Hopkins converted them into
a 29-23 half-time lead and
extended that to 40-29 five
minutes into the second half.
At that point a "cross-body
block" by a Greyhound on
forward Drew Fender sent
him to the trainer's room but
the Jays continued their fine
play against a taller and
supposedly more talented
opponent and led 48-41 with
7:38 remaining. At that
point, Hopkins lost its poise,
Loyola lost its' jitters and the
Blue Jays lost the game.
The Hounds outscored
Hopkins 10-2 over the next
3½ minutes and took the lead
51-50 with four minutes to go
and built that up to 55-50 at
the two minute mark.
The waning moments of
the game were marked by a
parade to the foul line by
both squads and a number of
missed opportunities by
Loyola to put the game on ice
and by Hopkins to pull it out
of the fire.
Statistically, Hopkins
players top a number of
departments in the MAC
Fender is second in field goal
percentage (68%), and Dan
Kopcza is second in both
rebounding (12.3 rpg.) and
free throw shooting (82%).
Following tonight's game
with the Green Terrors, the
Blue Jays return home
tomorrow night to face
Albright College at 8:1 5 p.m.

Between the mob and the men in blue: Crazy Joey
By RUSS SMITH
"Born in Red Hook,
Brooklyn in the year of who
knows when
Opened up his eyes, to the
tune of the accordion
Always on the outside, of
whatever side there was
When they asked him why
it had to be that way
Well, the answer was just
because
Larry was the oldest, Joey
Was next to last
They called Joe craxy, the
baby they called Kid Blast
Some said they lived off
gambling, and running
numbers too
Always seemed they caught
between, the mob and the
men in blue
Joey. Joey
King of the streets, child of
pain
Joey, Joey
What made them want to
come and blow you away."
—"Joey," Bob Dylan
Joey Gallo never had it so
good.
Almost four years ago,
Gallo was gunned down in
Umberto's Clam House, a
small restaurant in New
York's Little Italy. Ile was
the victim of a classic
gangland execution, one that
was suspiciously similar to a
scene in the most famous film
of the day, "The Godfather."
Gallo's obituaries depicted
him as a mean and hard-nosed
killer, a "maverick mafioso"
who boasted of being picked
up by the cops 150 times.
The newsweeklies told tales
of Gallo "puncturing his
enemies with iee picks just for
the hell of it" and "gaining
status by serving as a member
f a five man execution squad

dirtected by mafia boss Joe
Profaci in the late fifties.
Gallo's was the most difficult
kind of death for the public
to react to; no one likes to
hear of death, particularly
cold-blooded murder, but in
Gallo's case only an insider
could share in his family's
grief. In short, public school
in New York was not closed
in mourning for Joey Gallo.
Not even in Little Italy.
Therefore, it is not
surprising that a number of
people, especially New
Yorkers, are perplexed by
Bob Dylan's glorification of
Joey Gallo's crime and
bullet-ridden life on his latest
album,Desire.
Dylan takes a professed
"hard-as-nails" gangster and
portrays him as a family man
who, as a pawn of chance,
was led astray. According to
Dylan, Gallo never carried a
gun because "I'm around too
many children, they should
neven know of one." He sings
of Gallo's release from Attica
prison; "they let him out in
'71, he lost a little weight, but
he dressed like Jimmy
Cagney, and I swear he did
look great." To one who is
not familiar with Gallo the
romanticism is just another
element of the song, meshed
well with Dylan's finest vocal
and phrasing on the album.
However, for those who grew
up reading page three stories
and photo spreads about
Gallo's killings and mob
dealings in newspapers like
the New York Daily News
and National Enquirer, the
song is unsettling at best.
Dylan's intentions remain a
puzzle. Was he consciously
attempting to rescue Gallo

from the ranks of Mafia
infamy or was he taken in by
the folksy aura that "led
some of his superficial
acquantances to consider him
a sort of folk hero"? It's hard
to believe that Dylan, a
resident of New York
throughout the sixties, would
write such a naive ballad
about a mobster who
delighted in breaking arms
and spitting at subordinates.
They didn't call Joey Gallo
crazy for nothing.
It seems more probable
that Gallo's new status as a
martyr and folk hero was
calculated very carefully by
Dylan. By decriminalizing
Gallo, Dylan has placed Gallo

on the pedestal shared by the
likes of Jesse James and Billy
the Kid, two of the
songwriter's favorite models
in previous work. James and
Billy the Kid have been
cloaked in mystique since
their death and as the years
pass their image grows while
their villainous lives are
forgotten. Of course, it takes
more than one song for a
legend of this type to catch
on, but it is songs like "Joey"
that add to a myth and spread
it.
Thirty years from now,
after Gallo's crimes have been
forgotten, the gangster will
have been transformed into
"Joey, king of the streets,

child of clay." All that will
survive will be the legend of
Joey Gallo and Dylan will be
lost in the years, for a legend
is bigger than any man.
That Dylan uses a
contemporary gangster as his
latest folk model is an
example of his desperate need
for changing his music and
writing. The main differences '
in Dylan's writing about Gallo
instead of the bandit John
Wesley Hardin is that the
latter was already an
established legend before'
Dylan was even born. He just
paid homage to the myth by
adding another song. But with
Gallo, the implications of the
song are more meaningful.
because by eulogizing Gallo
he is creating another myth,
instead of simply adding to it.
In this sense, Dylan is playing
with history and folk culture
by intentionally whitewashing
a man who was repulsive to
most of the society in which
he lived.
By recognizing this process
it is easy to imagine that Jesse
James and John Wesley
Hardin were every bit as
notorious and gun thirsty as
Gallo. Dylan realizes this.
which is why he titles the song
as anonymous "Joey"
instead of something more
direct like "The Ballad of
Joey Gallo." That was the
first step in Gallo's
decriminalization.
Whether Dylan's sense of
morality and historical
perspective are out of line is
something that most listeners
will not be able to agree on.
But, like it or not, there now
V seems to be one more myth
to deal with: .the legend of
crazy Joe.

As the reverberations of
Rolling Thunder echoed
tIi roughout the East Coast.

per
end of 1967. Dylan realized

silenced cries for "the old

emotional intensity of
Dylan's music has been
effective enough to cause
many to conclude that Dylan
gave the generation of the
sixties a voice. Dylan's songs
somehow capture the travail

Stayin' up for days in a

Writin"Sad-Eyed Lady of

bearing signs of being

"Sara." As Lorca had his

letters to the editor
To the Editor:
1 take my teaching
seriously. I take student
responses to my teaching
seriously. For that reason I
wish to take the unusual step
of responding to several
related points in the Fall
1975 Course Evaluation of
my "Changing China" course.
The course guide, based I
believe in part on an
inaccurate assessment of
certain facts and in part on an
all -too -reasonable
misunderstanding of other
facts, states: "Grading is
rather strict and even a bit
prejudicial—i.e., essay exam
questions are vague and must
be answered just right and
favorably to China. Dr.
Pfeffer considers a 'C' a good
grade and the majority of
grades given out were 'good
grades'."
In response, I do not and
never have considered a "C" a
good grade. Personally, I
consider it less than
satisfactory work, and I tell
my students that. Moreover,
the last time the course was
offered, under the title

"China Today," the majority
of grades were not "C's," as
the report seems to imply. To
be precise, of the 16 grades
given, 3 Were "A's," 7 were
"B's" and only 3 were "C's:"
one was a pass and two were
incompletes. The only
substance to the charge that
"grading is rather strict" is
that I have resisted the total
surrender to grade inflation
reflected at Hopkins today.
More importantly, the
report charges that my
grading is "even a bit
prejudicial"—equivalent to
the kiss of death in a
"value -free," liberal
university. And further that
essay exam questions are
"vague" and "must be
answered just right and
favorably to China." This is a
more complex and difficult
charge to rebut, involving as it
does different ideologies. Let
me try to respond.
First, I do not think that
my grading is any more
"prejudicial" than any other
professor's in the social
sciences or humanities. My
prejudices simply are not

those widely shared by
faculty members and
students, so they are more
obvious. I do not try to
disguise my values.
Nevertheless, I believe I
recognize quality work when
I see it, and I have given
"A's" to well conceived and
executed papers that argued
Mao is a fascist, and
conversely, I have given "C's"
to poorly written,
unthoughtful essays that
simply parrot "the line." In
the final analysis, however, I
recognize that one's ideology
cannot help but influence
how one conceives relevance
and significance. On that
count, I would, with the rest
of humanity, plead guilty.
Second, it is true that my
essay questions are "vague."
They are intended to be, so as
to allow students within a
wide range to answer them as
they think most useful, to
make the questions their own.
That they must be answered
"just right," I think is wrong,
unless by "right" is meant
that the answer must be
logical, well-written,

argumentative, and with some
reasonable connection to
historical fact and a
reasonable use of evidence to
support the arguments. One
rather frequent, half-pained
comment I have had to these
essay questions is that they
"forced" students to think.
Another is that they "forced"
students to try to learn how
to discipline their writing. I
like to believe that is what I
am doing.
That essays must be
favorable to China to be
considered good is, as
indicated above, clearly
wiong as a flat statement. But
the matter is more complex
than .that. My main
substantive goal in the course
is to try to enable students to
understand the Chinese
Revolution in its own terms,
as the Chinese saw it. We
cannot understand why and
how that revolution has
developed if we pose liberal
questions to twentieth
century China, or if we judge
China's Revolution by liberal
standards. China has never
been, is not no'w, art does

not wish to become a liberal
society
I demand is not that
students react "favorably" to
the Chinese Revolution but
that they reach an
understanding of the
revolution in its own terms as
a basis for whatever ultimate
evaluation they may wish to
make. To do otherwise, it
seems to me, entails simply
abdicating on the crucial
matter of understanding a
society so different from and
so alien to our society, and
results in self-satisfying
condemnations of China as
illiberal.
These are difficult matters

least) 9-1 record.
Reconstruction
"I was a little bit worried
at the beginning of the season
and then after losing two
additional fencers I was
scared stiff!", noted Oles.
"But with what we have now
we could probably win all but
3 of our remaining meets and
finish 16-4 despite a
rebuilding team."
On epee, Rodgers and Slota
return and according to Oles,
are fencing as well as last year
and that was good enough to
capture titles in both the
MAC and the NAC' No. 3
epee man Frank Murabito

defeated Montclair State's
No. 1 man who, ironically,
defeated both Rodgers and
Slota. Overall, Oles termed
this team as good as last
year's.
"Our foil team is not right
now as good as last year's.
But by the end of the season I
think they will be better than
last year's because there
won't be one flash and three
mediocre fencers. Now we
have better balance,"
according to Oles.
Dave Bell, Dave Graberek
and Eric Newman compose
that trio.
Sabre
"Right now of course,
sabre is our weak link because
we've lost essentially our Nos.
1,2,3 and 4 men from last
season's sabre unit. Our No. 1
man is Ron Kramer who is
our only undefeated fencer
(18-0). He is vastly improved
over last year and could win

the MAC title. No. 2
Streamson Chua and No. 3
Mark Harrison are also
becoming competent
fencers."
The Homewood mentor
concluded,"If everybody
fences as well as they can
then we can win the MAC and
have a longshot at the NAC,
depending on how Chua
comes along because we'll
only need our top two fencers
in each weapon."'
Co-captains Tim Rodgers
and Ron Kramer echoed their
coach's optimistic sentiments.
In looking toward
Saturday's match with
Lafayette, Kramer noted,"We
should repeat as MAC champs
this year and this will be a
good test to see how we stand
vs. up-and-coming MAC
competition." The match will
begin at 2:00 p.m. in the
Hopkins fencing room of the
Athletic Center.

Future lies before inexperienced wrestlers
By DAVID KRAUS
The accent is on the future
as the Johns Hopkins
wrestling team moves into the
second half of its 1975-76
schedule.
First-year coach John
Glascock began the season
with no returning starters
from last year's 8-5 squad and
has turned to a spirited group
of underclassmen to carry the
team.
Sporting a starting line-up
dominated by freshmen and
sophmores, the Blue Jays had
their opening matches in early
December. However, the lack
of team experience proved
costly as they dropped
decisions to UMBC (44-10)
and to Washington College
(27-21).
The new year saw the
losing streak continue as
Susquehanna downed the
men from Homewood.by the
count of 33-12. However, the
Jays broke into the win
column with their next bout.
Led by freshman Muraji
Nakazawa and sophomore
captain McLin Hawkins (a
transfer student from West
Point), Hopkinds thumped
Charles Street rival Loyola,
33-15. Loyola took an early
lead, but several consecutive
victories in the late bouts
assured the Homewood
victory.

This past Saturday, the
Blue Jays travelled to
Lebanon Valley where they
participated in a quadrangular
meet against three different
colleges, including the host
school. Hopkins came away
with a record of 1-2 for the
afternoon, having beaten
Albright, 28-24, while losing
to Scranton, 30-9, and to
Lebanon Valley, 39-11.
Coach Glascock seemed
satisfied with his team's
effort.
"It's tough in the
quadrangular meets," he
explained. "That's a lot of
wrestling in one afternoon.
"I knew Lebanon Valley
would be tough-- they're an
excellent team. Scranton
surprised us— I didn't think
that they'd be as tough as
they were.
"Albright was a hard
match, too. All the guys put
out and it came down to the
last match— which we won."
The team's most recent
bout was Wednesday evening
when Western Maryland
invaded Homewood. The
Green Terrors have a very
powerful squad this year and
had little trouble in
vanquishing the Blue Jays,
46-6.
The only bright spots for
Hopkins were Nakazawa and
Hawkins. Each decisioned

their respective opponent to
keep their personal
undefeated records intact.
Muraji is now 8-0, while
McLin (who missed the first
two matches of the year) is
6-0.
Glscock attributes the
slow start of his team (now
2-6 on the year) to several
factors.

"The team coalesced very
slowly," he noted."We didn't
know who would be returning
from last year's squad and I
was developing a feel for
coaching. In addition, we had
a very large influx of
freshmen.
"However, I would have
thought that our record
would be stronger

during the past two seasons.
The visiting Hounds' 59-56
come from behind win
marked the fifth time in two
years and the second time this
season (79-64 Dec. ( in the,
Metro Tourney) that second
year coach Toni O'Connor
and his charges have
triumphed over the Jays.
A tenacious 2-1-2 zone
defense complemented the
Blue Jays' normal
man-to-man and the two •
combined to force Loyola out
of its normal offense and
caused a number of
Greyhound turnovers.
Hopkins converted them into
a 29-23 half-time lead and
extended that to 40-29 five
minutes into the second half.
At that point a "cross-body
block" by a Greyhound on
forward Drew Fender sent
him to the trainer's room but
the Jays continued their fine
play against a taller and
supposedly more talented
opponent and led 48-41 with
7:38 remaining. At that
point, Hopkins lost its poise,
Loyola lost its' jitters and the
Blue Jays lost the game.
The Hounds outscored
Hopkins 10-2 over the next
3½ minutes and took the lead
51-50 with four minutes to go
and built that up to 55-50 at
the two minute mark.
The waning moments of
the game were marked by a
parade to the foul line by
both squads and a number of
missed opportunities by
Loyola to put the game on ice
and by Hopkins to pull it out
of the fire.
Statistically, Hopkins
players top a number of
departments in the MAC
Fender is second in field goal
percentage (68%), and Dan
Kopcza is second in both
rebounding (12.3 rpg.) and
free throw shooting (82%).
Following tonight's game
with the Green Terrors, the
Blue Jays return home
tomorrow night to face
Albright College at 8:1 5 p.m.

Women fencers start year well
The excellent coaching job
done by both head coach
Dick Oles and his assistant
Gary Green extends not only
to the men's fencing team but
to the other side of the
"strip" as well.
They have put together a
women's fencing team which
thus far has compiled a 4-1
record which, but for a quirk
in schedueling could just as
well have been perfect.
Loss
"The only match that our
women lost was their fourth
of the day (St. John's of
N.Y.) and even then they
3nly lost by two touches.
There's no doubt in my
mind," said Oles firmly,"that
if we were fresh, we would
have won!"
"We have a better schedule

than last year," Oles
continued," in that our
opponents are harder. But
nevertheless I don't see us
losing more than three more
meets the entire year."
Unlike the men who fence
three men at three different
weapons, women fence only
with one: foil, using four
combatants.
Lwee Kelleher is without a
doubt the Jays top fencer
(18-1) and one of the nation's
top women fencers as well.
"Our No. 2 woman is
senior co-captain Leslie Parpal
and after three ysars with her
I wasn't sure if I'd ever make
a fencer out of her. But
something happened during
intersession and she put it all
together."
Oles grinned,"She's like a
man in the respect that she

lights like hell; she's mean!
And I mean all that as a
compliment!"
Close Contenders
Anne Murphy (No. 3) and
Carol Clarke (No. 4) round
out the top four but there are
three other women who could
break into the first four at
any time--Arna Cohen,
Joanne Julius and Lida
Atallah. "It's only a question
of time," said Oles, "when
they put it all together."
"We're competitive with
anybody on our schedule."
Oles noted. "As good as any
and better than most! For
nationals what we do depends
on how far our Nos. 2.3 and 4
women develop."
And, knowing Oles.
nothing short of a
championship would be
unexpected!
